prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not sharing food with my best friend
My best friend and I live together. He doesn't pay any bills, he lives here for free. He doesn't pay for groceries. He doesn't have a car, I take us everywhere. 

Sometimes he's loud, sometimes he's dirty and he smells, but I put up with it all because he's my best friend. 

Now, on to the question, everytime I eat he wants a portion of my meal. It's not like he doesn't have food either, I always make sure there's enough food for both of us - albeit not always the same type of food. He doesn't outrightly say anything, he usually just stares at me until either I give in or don't. Usually I do. 

[Pic for context.](https://i.imgur.com/8QJkJle.jpg)

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the person who wrote the "AITA" (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong for not sharing their food with their best friend. 

First, let's look at the situation. The author and their best friend live together. The friend doesn't pay any bills or groceries and lives there for free. The author also takes the friend everywhere since they don't have a car. The friend is described as loud, dirty, and smelly, but the author puts up with it because they're friends. 

The main issue is the friend wanting a portion of the author's meal every time they eat. The author says they make sure there's enough food for both, but not always the same type. The friend doesn't outright ask but stares until the author gives in. The author usually does.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong for not sharing. Let's break it down. The friend isn't contributing financially, so maybe the expectation of sharing food is unfair. The author is providing food for both, but when they make different meals, the friend wants a share. If the author is making a meal for themselves, it's reasonable to expect that they can eat what they made without being forced to share. The friend's nonverbal pressure (staring) to share might be manipulative. 

On the other hand, since they're living together and friends, maybe there's an expectation of sharing resources. But the friend isn't contributing, which complicates things. The author is already tolerating other issues like noise and cleanliness. Sharing food could be seen as part of living together, but if the author is making specific meals they don't want to split, it's their right to keep their own food. The friend's behavior of staring until the author gives in might be considered controlling or inconsiderate. 

I think the key points are that the author isn't the one asking for anything, they're the ones providing shelter and food without contribution from the friend. The friend's insistence on sharing the author's meal without contributing might be the real issue here. So the author isn't in the wrong for not sharing, especially if the friend isn't respecting boundaries. Therefore, the answer should be B (No).
